a brief intro to git
This tutorial assumes you are proficient with command line, have git installed, and are familiar with version control. We'll walk through some basic commands to get comfortable with git.
We'll use a test/ directory that contains two empty files: one.txt and two.txt.
git init initializes a repository in your current directory.
Run git init and you'll see 
Initialized empty Git repository in test/
git status shows you the files that are staged for a commit.
Run git status and you'll see
On branch master

Initial commit

Untracked files:
(use "git add ..." to include in what will be committed)

one.txt
two.txt

nothing added to commit but untracked files present (use "git add" to track)
We'll use git status frequently to examine our staging area.
git add (file name) stages that file.
git add . stages all files.
Run git add . and git status and you'll see one.txt and two.txt are in staging.
On branch master

Initial commit

Changes to be committed:
(use "git rm --cached ..." to unstage)

new file:   one.txt
new file:   two.txt
If you want to unstage a file, use git rm --cached (file name).
Run git rm --cached -r . and you'll see 
rm 'one.txt'
rm 'two.txt'
git commit -m (message) creates a commit from staged files. Each commit has a unique hash based on your message, name, email, and commit time.

If you removed your files from staging, add them to staging again.
Run git commit -m 'add one.txt and two.txt' and you'll see 
[master (root-commit) 70c5add] add one.txt and two.txt
2 files changed, 0 insertions(+), 0 deletions(-)
create mode 100644 one.txt
create mode 100644 two.txt
Run git status and you'll see 
On branch master
nothing to commit, working directory clean
You made a commit and your staging area is clean.
git log shows your commit history.
Run git log and you'll see something like
commit 70c5add089ce283769d9ce32766794dccf165d4e
Author: lyn han 
Date:   Wed Mar 23 15:52:57 2016 -0500

    add one.txt and two.txt
Your commit hash will be different because your have different author and date. Add some text to one.txt and make another commit so that git log shows two commits.
commit 06390f1e539f60210026d03c7d3e7bdc592e36de
Author: lyn han 
Date:   Wed Mar 23 16:46:41 2016 -0500

    add text to one.txt

commit 70c5add089ce283769d9ce32766794dccf165d4e
Author: lyn han 
Date:   Wed Mar 23 15:52:57 2016 -0500

    add one.txt and two.txt
git checkout reverts your files back to what they looked a commit. Use git checkout (commit hash) for a single commit and git checkout master to go to the latest version.
Run git checkout 06380f and you'll see 
Note: checking out '06390f'.

You are in 'detached HEAD' state. You can look around, make experimental
changes and commit them, and you can discard any commits you make in this
state without impacting any branches by performing another checkout.

If you want to create a new branch to retain commits you create, you may
do so (now or later) by using -b with the checkout command again. Example:

  git checkout -b 

HEAD is now at 06390f1... add text to one.txt
You have reverted your files to their states at the first commit. Look around and you'll see that the files are empty.
To go back to the latest version, run git checkout master and you'll see 
Switched to branch 'master'
Look around again and you'll see that one.txt has the latest text.
Congratulations! You now know your way around basic git commands. Visit the documentation to learn more about advance git commands and read this guide to learn about how git works under the hood.
